A2.text: The number of address lines required to access $2^{10}$ memory locations is:

B1.text: Explain the difference between RISC and CISC architectures with suitable examples.

C1.text: With a neat diagram, explain the internal organization of a $4 \times 4$ RAM chip. Derive the expression for total memory capacity when $n$ such chips are connected.

A2.solution: To address $2^{10} = 1024$ locations, you need $\log_2(1024) = 10$ address lines.

B1.solution:
**RISC (Reduced Instruction Set Computer):**
- Fixed-length instructions
- Load/store architecture
- Large number of registers
- Examples: ARM, MIPS, RISC-V

**CISC (Complex Instruction Set Computer):**
- Variable-length instructions
- Memory-to-memory operations allowed
- Fewer registers
- Examples: x86, x86-64

**Key Difference:** RISC executes one instruction per clock cycle using pipelining. CISC instructions may take multiple cycles but reduce code size.
key_points: RISC has fixed instruction length; CISC has variable

C1.solution:
A $4 \times 4$ RAM chip has:
- 4 memory locations (2 address lines: $A_0, A_1$)
- 4-bit data width ($D_0$ to $D_3$)
- CS (Chip Select), WE (Write Enable) control lines

**Diagram:** [4Ã—4 RAM internal organization with decoder and storage cells]

**When n chips connected in parallel (expanding word width):**
$$\text{Total capacity} = 4 \times (4 \times n) \text{ bits} = 16n \text{ bits}$$

**When n chips connected for address expansion:**
$$\text{Total capacity} = (4 \times n) \times 4 \text{ bits} = 16n \text{ bits}$$

In both cases, total capacity scales linearly with $n$.

Explain CS line for chip selection
